text: Where does AI fit into the workplace and how should companies manage it once it's there? So, I want to speak with you first about this discussion about whether AI is going to cause folks to lose jobs or potentially create more jobs. You see it often in your position. You see the data. Yeah. So, can you weigh in a little bit in terms of where this is going and where it is today? Yeah. So, for us at networks, we've had to really lean into AI. Like I'll talk to some peers at other companies that are like taking a really cautious approach. You know, hey, we can't let any AI generated code get into the product, for example, or you know, we want to be careful about how we use AI in decisioning. , for us, we had to be really aggressive. So, we leaned into AI a lot. as to whether it's going to create jobs or or kill jobs, absolutely going to create jobs. There's so much unmet demand in our industry. Like, if I could have every developer be 10 times more efficient, I'd hire double the developers, right? We'd be able to move the bar ahead so much more. And I think we'd do it at kind of a lower like total cost per per dollar of output, if you will. And so, for us, it's it's just massive demand. Our problem is not, hey, we need to save money. You can't cut your way to great growth or great products or great customer experiences. For us, it's like, how can we double down on that? Man, we we'll start growing with that. We're going to hire a ton more people. Yeah. When people are saying, "Okay, AI can do someone else's jobs." Yeah. I think that's just such a short-sighted way of looking at it often. Yeah.
